HTMLScriptElement.summary: JavaScript files should be served with the text/javascript MIME type, but browsers are lenient and block them only if the script is served with an image type (image/*), video type (video/*), audio type (audio/*), or text/csv. If the script is blocked, its element receives an event; otherwise, it receives a event.

blockquote.para: When inserted using the method, {{HTMLElement("script")}} elements execute (typically synchronously), but when inserted using or , they do not execute at all.

remarks.para:
-HTML script element
-HTML noscript element
-
-Web Workers (code snippets similar to scripts but executed in another global context)

HTMLScriptElementAsync.summary: The async property of the interface is a boolean value that controls how the script should be executed. For classic scripts, if the async property is set to true, the external script will be fetched in parallel to parsing and evaluated as soon as it is available. For module scripts, if the async property is set to true, the script and all their dependencies will be fetched in parallel to parsing and evaluated as soon as they are available.

remarks.para: It reflects the async attribute of the script element.

HTMLScriptElementAttributionSrc.summary: IMPORTANT Deprecated The attributionSrc property of the interface gets and sets the attributionsrc attribute on a script element programmatically, reflecting the value of that attribute. attributionsrc specifies that you want the browser to send an Attribution-Reporting-Eligible header along with the script resource request.

remarks.para: On the server-side this is used to trigger sending an Attribution-Reporting-Register-Source or Attribution-Reporting-Register-Trigger header in the response, to register a JavaScript-based attribution source or attribution trigger, respectively. Which response header should be sent back depends on the value of the Attribution-Reporting-Eligible header that triggered the registration.

blockquote.para: Alternatively, JavaScript-based attribution sources or triggers can be registered by sending a request containing the attributionReporting option (either set directly on the fetch() call or on a object passed into the fetch() call), or by sending an with invoked on the request object.

remarks.para: See the Attribution Reporting API for more details.
-Attribution Reporting API.

HTMLScriptElementAttributionSrc.value: A string. There are two versions of this property that you can get and set:

HTMLScriptElementBlocking.summary: The read-only blocking property of the returns a live object containing the operations that should be blocked on the fetching of an external resource. It reflects the {{HTMLElement("script")}} element's blocking content attribute.
HTMLScriptElementBlocking.value: A live object.Although the blocking property itself is read-only in the sense that you can't replace the DOMTokenList object, you can still assign to the blocking property directly, which is equivalent to assigning to its property. You can also modify the DOMTokenList object using the , , , and methods.

HTMLScriptElementCrossOrigin.summary: The crossOrigin property of the interface reflects the {{Glossary("CORS", "Cross-Origin Resource Sharing")}} settings for the script element. For classic scripts from other origins, this controls if full error information will be exposed. For module scripts, it controls the script itself and any script it imports. See CORS settings attributes for details.
HTMLScriptElementCrossOrigin.value: A string of a keyword specifying the CORS mode to use when fetching the resource. Possible values are:If the crossOrigin property is specified with any other value, it is the same as specifying it as the anonymous.If the crossOrigin property is not specified, the resource is fetched without CORS (the no-cors {{domxref("Request.mode", "mode", "", "nocode")}} and the same-origin {{domxref("Request.credentials", "credentials", "", "nocode")}} mode).

HTMLScriptElementDefer.summary: The defer property of the interface is a boolean value that controls how the script should be executed. For classic scripts, if the defer property is set to true, the external script will be executed after the document has been parsed, but before firing event. For module scripts, the defer property has no effect.

remarks.para: It reflects the defer attribute of the script element.

HTMLScriptElementFetchPriority.summary:
The fetchPriority property of the interface represents a hint to the browser indicating how it should prioritize fetching an external script relative to other external scripts.
It reflects the <script> element's fetchpriority content attribute.

remarks.para:
-
-
-HTTP Link header
-Optimize resource loading with the Fetch Priority API for information about how this API affects priorities on Chrome.

HTMLScriptElementFetchPriority.value: A string. For the permitted values, see the HTML fetchpriority attribute.

summary.blockquote:
WARNINGThis property represents the text content of a script element, which may be executable depending on the script type.
APIs like this are known as injection sinks, and are potentially a vector for cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks.

remarks.para:
You can mitigate this risk by always assigning objects instead of strings and enforcing trusted types.
See Security considerations for more information.

The innerText property of the interface represents the text content of the {{HTMLElement("script")}} element.
It behaves in the same way as the and properties.

HTMLScriptElementInnerText.value: Getting the property returns a string containing the scripts's text.Setting the property accepts either a object or a string.

HTMLScriptElementIntegrity.summary: The integrity property of the interface is a string that contains inline metadata that a browser can use to verify that a fetched resource has been delivered without unexpected manipulation.

remarks.para: It reflects the integrity attribute of the script element.

-
-Subresource Integrity

HTMLScriptElementNoModule.summary: The noModule property of the interface is a boolean value that indicates whether the script should be executed in browsers that support ES modules. Practically, this can be used to serve fallback scripts to older browsers that do not support JavaScript modules.

remarks.para: It reflects the nomodule attribute of the script element.

HTMLScriptElementNoModule.value: A boolean, true means that the script should not be executed in browsers that support ES modules, false otherwise.

HTMLScriptElementReferrerPolicy.summary:
The referrerPolicy property of the
interface reflects the HTML
referrerpolicy of the script element, which defines how the referrer is set when fetching the script and any scripts it imports.
HTMLScriptElementReferrerPolicy.value:
A string; one of the following:
NOTEAn empty string value ("") is both the default
value, and a fallback value if referrerpolicy is not supported. If
referrerpolicy is not explicitly specified on the
<script> element, it will adopt a higher-level referrer policy,
i.e., one set on the whole document or domain. If a higher-level policy is not
available, the empty string is treated as being equivalent to
no-referrer-when-downgrade.

summary.blockquote:
WARNINGThis property represents the URI of an external script loaded into the script element, which may be executable depending on the script .
APIs like this are known as injection sinks, and are potentially a vector for cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks.

remarks.para:
You can mitigate this risk by having a Content Security Policy (CSP) that restricts the locations from which scripts can be loaded, and by always assigning objects instead of strings and enforcing trusted types.
See Security considerations for more information.
The src property of the interface is a string representing the URL of an external script; this can be used as an alternative to embedding a script directly within a document.
It reflects the src attribute of the script element.

HTMLScriptElementSrc.value: Getting the property returns a string containing the element's script URI.Setting the property accepts either a object or a string.

HTMLScriptElementSupports.summary: The supports() static method of the interface provides a simple and consistent method to feature-detect what types of scripts are supported by the user agent.

remarks.para: The method is expected to return true for classic and module scripts, which are supported by most modern browsers.

-
-script
-JavaScript modules
- constructor

HTMLScriptElementSupports.returns: Returns true if the indicated script type is supported and false otherwise.

summary.blockquote:
WARNINGThis property represents the text content of a script element, which may be executable depending on the script type.
APIs like this are known as injection sinks, and are potentially a vector for cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks.

remarks.para:
You can mitigate this risk by always assigning objects instead of strings and enforcing trusted types.
See Security considerations for more information.

The text property of the interface represents the inline text content of the {{HTMLElement("script")}} element.
It behaves in the same way as the and property.

HTMLScriptElementText.value: Getting the property returns a string containing the script's text.Setting the property accepts either a object or a string.

summary.blockquote:
WARNINGThis property represents the text content of a script element, which may be executable depending on the script type.
APIs like this are known as injection sinks, and are potentially a vector for cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks.

remarks.para:
You can mitigate this risk by always assigning objects instead of strings and enforcing trusted types.
See Security considerations for more information.

The textContent property of the interface represents the inline text content of the {{HTMLElement("script")}} element.
It behaves in the same way as the and properties.

HTMLScriptElementTextContent.value: Getting the property returns a string containing the script's text.Setting the property accepts either a object or a string.

HTMLScriptElementType.summary: The type property of the interface is a string that reflects the type of the script.

remarks.para: It reflects the type attribute of the script element.

HTMLScriptElementType.value: A string. The value of this property can be one of the following:For more information, please refer to the type attribute of the script element.
